Dear Dave,

I'm writing because I'm having trouble figuring out how to comb=
ine 2 
(or better, multiple) kinetics reactors in pressure equilibrium 
whi=
ch are subject to an imposed Vdot.

I read your response to a similar quest=
ion dated Feb04 (and your 
zerod.pdf), but I still don't quite understand.
=

For example, if I have two reactors 1 and 2, and would like to have 
the P=
(1)=3DP(2), but Vdot(1 and 2)=3Dsome function, would the setup be 
as such?=


           ||
Reactor 1  ||  Reactor 2
           ||
  Wall wA-flexible
 =
 Wall wB-Vdot-prescribed


or, would it be more like


           |        =
     |
Reactor 1  |  Reactor 2  |  Reservoir 3
           |             |
 =
 Wall wA-flexible   wall wB-Vdot-prescribed


Thanks for any tips you can g=
ive me.
-Daniel Braithwaite



<<<
On Feb,2004 Dave Goodwin wrote:

It is c=
urrently not possible to specify a function for the rate at
which a wall mo=
ves from Matlab, but you can do it from Python. If you
want to run your sim=
ulation in Python, all you need to do is this:

1) Create 2 reactors that s=
hare a common wall (A), and make it 
flexible
enough to maintain pressure e=
quilibrium.
2) Add a second wall (B) to reactor 2 with a specified vdot rat=
e vs.
time. This will actually change the total volume, not just volume 2,
=
with time, since the rate of volume change for each reactor is 
computed
by=
 summing over all of its walls. Thus, the rate of change of volume 
of
reac=
tor 1 plus reactor 2 equals the specified vdot for wall B: 
dV/dt_1
+ dV/dt=
_2 =3D vdot(A) + (vdot(B) - vdot(A)) =3D vdot(B).

The only reason this can=
't be done from Matlab too is that I haven't
gotten around to adding the ne=
cessary interfacing code to the Matlab
toolbox. It's not hard to do, and I'=
ll add it to the list of 
requested
enhancements.

Dave Goodwin



On Feb 1=
8, 2004, at 7:37 AM, thomassteinhilber wrote:

> Dear Mr. Goodwin,
>
> I=B4=
m a PhD student at the Technical University of Munich and using
> Cantera f=
or the simulation of gas compression up to auto-ignition.
> With little cha=
nges to your matlab demo "ignite2" I managed the
> compression of one gas-v=
olume (wich was actually quite easy, thanks
> for the good demo versions!).=

>
> Now I would like to compress two, coupled reactors, with pressure
> eq=
uilibrium. Input is the volume change of the total volume (Volume
> (Reacto=
r1)+Volume(Reactor2)). In your Python-description "Zero-
> Dimensional Kine=
tics" I found the command
>
> vrate=3DPolynomial([5.0, -1.0, 10.0])
> wall1=
.set(Vdot=3Dvrate)
>
> Is this command also available for Matlab, or do you=
 have a better
> idea to compress two volumina with a given volume change?
=
>
> Thank you,
> Thomas Steinhilber
